Dear Ms. Raubenolt:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
July 18, 2019. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the ISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.
Sincerely,
Deborah Will, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is following all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for the
following:
R 400.12205 Required staff.
(8) An agency shall employ or contract for a sufficient number of
competent staff to carry out the provisions covered by these
rules. The workload for each staff member shall not be more
than any of the following:
(b) Fifteen children assigned to a social services worker for
purposes of providing direct services in foster care, independent
living, adoption, or post adoption services or a combination
thereof.
One of four adoption workers has twenty adoption cases
assigned.
R 400.12209 Orientation and training.
(1) An agency shall ensure and document that each social
service worker and each social service supervisor
receives not less than 16 hours of orientation after initial
appointment and before assumption of assigned duties.
One of twelve new employees had no verification that she
was oriented to her job duties.
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(b) Verification of education
One of twelve new employees hired in March 2019 is unable
to produce a diploma or official transcript from Wayne
State because she carries an unpaid balance to the
university. However, unofficial transcripts and a letter from
4

the university indicate she was awarded a bachelor’s
degree.
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(h) Documentation from the department that the person has
not been named in a central registry case as the perpetrator
of child abuse or neglect in Michigan or in any state where
the person lived in the 5 years preceding hire.
One of twelve new employees transferred from another
Judson program into Judson’s foster care program without
an updated central registry clearance.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
Three of six reevaluation recommendations were not sent
to the department at least 15 days before the foster home
expiration date.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child's
record before a change of placement occurs:
(a) – (j)
One of one DHHS-69 which is used to document the
requirements of this rule was completed one month after
the replacement occurred.
5

(repeat violation)
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
Two of four ISPs were completed late by 3 & 6 days.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Seven of 17 USPs were completed late by 1, 1, 2, 2, 7, 11 &
19 days.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(3) When case responsibility changes from 1 child placing
agency to another child placing agency, a modified service plan
must be completed within 30 calendar days of the change in
agency responsibility if no other plan is done within 30 days.
The plan shall address why the agency responsibility changed
and whether there are any modifications to existing service
plans.
One of two modified service plans did not include why the
agency responsibility changed.
2.) The facility is complying will all ISEP requirements.
6

3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that there
are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in section
1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements
except for the following:
FOM 802, pg 1 Mental Health Screening within 30 days
One of six foster children did not have a mental health
screening within 30 days.
FOM 802, pg 2 Caseworker role in health documentation – The caseworker
is responsible.
One of six foster children had computer-printed health records
from the provider that were indecipherable. Standard DHHS
well-child exam forms were not used. The caseworker is
responsible for knowing and understanding the child’s health
care and condition.
FOM 801, pg 11 Medical passports provided to the caregiver
For one of six foster children, two quarterly medical passports
were not signed by the foster parent.
FOM 722-06B Quarterly FTMs
One of six foster children did not have an FTM in March 2019
(repeat non-compliance)
FOM 722-06I, Sibling visits are to occur monthly
pg11
One of six foster children missed four of nine monthly sibling
visits. One of six foster children visited with his/her siblings
monthly. However, only six of the twelve visits were
documented.
7

(repeat non-compliance)
FOM 722-08C Caregiver signatures on PATPs
Two of twenty-one PATPs were not signed by the child’s
caregiver.
(repeat non-compliance)
SRM 200 SAT is required to be taken within six months of working in
a position with CW-CHRI access and every two years
thereafter.
Five of nineteen employees in a position with CHRI access were
in non-compliance.
(repeat non-compliance)
AFPRR Contract Relative foster homes are to be licensed within 1 year of
application
Three of twenty relative homes were not licensed within this
timeframe.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE – No CAPs needed
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R 400.12325 License recommendation.
(3) Except for an original license, an agency shall recommend to
the department the issuance of a regular license or the
continuation of an active license only when all rules are in
compliance or both of the following conditions exist:
(b) A written corrective action plan has been developed. The
plan shall be in compliance with all of the following
requirements:
(ii) Require that the corrective action be completed within
six (6) months of being signed.
8

Although the rule allows a maximum of six months for corrective action to be
completed, one foster parent was given four months to complete a fairly simple
CAP. The amount of time allowed to reach compliance should be limited
whenever possible.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(a) Submit a special investigation record to the department's
licensing authority within 5 working days in the manner
prescribed by the department.
DCWL was not notified of one special investigation within 5
days. The reason given was due to a MISACWIS issue.
When the required software impedes rule compliance, the
agency should strive to comply with rules by the use of
other forms of communication/documentation.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
 Unfinished and incomplete documents should never be uploaded until they
are determined complete. Do not scan and upload a document just to verify it
was sent or faxed to another party. Verification of sent documents can be
done through other methods such as email or initialing the printed version of
the document which is still maintained in the hard file.
 Information from another author or from previous reports by the same author
should not be copied and pasted into a current report.
 If the printed version of a report is inaccurate, correct it by striking out the
inaccurate information and handwriting in the correct information, i.e.,
inaccurate contacts & report periods that auto-populate. Inaccurate
documents should not be knowingly be placed into the hard file.
ANALYST’S CONCERNS
There were no concerns related to safety.
The following non-safety concerns were identified:
9

Alert 1
Concern: Foster children reported not being involved or signing their case service plan.
Resolution: Service plan date was 6/18/19. The agency had until 7/16/19 to obtain
signatures. Foster care worker was still working on obtaining signatures when the
analyst visited the child. Only one child is age 14 or above. The plan was discussed
with the child.
Alert 2
No Concerns
Alert 3
Concern: Foster parent reported that foster care workers made 5 unannounced home
visits in 2 years when she had a placement.
Resolution: From 7/10/17 – 2/26/19, six unannounced visits were required and seven
were completed. Unannounced visits were completed on the following dates: 7/13/17,
8/14/17, 11/22/17, 3/30/18, 6/29/18, 9/6/18 & 12/19/18.
Alert 4
Concern: Caregiver reported that foster care worker didn't make any unannounced
home visits.
Resolution: The agency received the case on 2/18/19. One unannounced visit was
required. It occurred on 4/25/19.
Concern: Caregiver also reported not receiving the medical passport.
Resolution: One medical passport was required. It was signed by the caregiver on
7/8/19.
Alert 5
No Concerns
Alert 6
Concern: Caregiver reported foster care worker hasn't made any unannounced
home visits.
Resolution: Judson Center received this case on 4/1/19. One unannounced visit
was required. An unannounced visit occurred 6/19/19.
Concern: Caregiver also reported not receiving the medical passport.
Resolution: The agency provided the medical passport when at the time of the service
plan. The relative placement signed it on 7/3/19.
10

EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. The CAP involved policy refresher training with the worker on behavior
management and signing another behavior management policy agreement.
The agency had no DCWL investigations during this licensing period.
Therefore, no corrective action plans were required.
For the 2018 Interim Report, the agency was cited and submitted a corrective
action plan for the following citations:
R 400.12205 (8) (c ) Required staff
R 400.12209 (1) Orientation and training
R 400.12212 (1) (d) Personnel records
R 400.12326 (1) (d) Borrowed home
R 400.12327 (1) (b), (2) (b), (5) (f) & (h) Special evaluation
R 400.12405 (3) (a – h) Change of placement (repeated in 2019)
R 400.12413 (2) Medical and dental
R 400.12417 (1) (c – g) Foster parent information
ISEP 6.18 Relative Foster Parent Licensing Timeliness
FOM 801 Follow up Health Care
FOM 722-06I Sibling visits (repeated in 2019)
FOM 722-06B Quarterly FTMs (repeated in 2019)
FOM 722-08C Foster parent/caregiver signature on PATPs (repeated in 2019)
SRM 200 SAT training (repeated in 2019)
VI. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
